We had our three year old with us and she was extremely helpful in helping us with the stroller etc that made it easy for us to truly enjoy the tour. If you are visiting HK for the first time this tour is a must do as you get to learn about its famous foods and walk around the main streets and learn its history.

Yummy Food Tour with Yammy!. My wife and I did the Sheung Wan and Central food tour with Yammy. It was our first visit to Hong Kong and this type of tour is a must for any visitor.. Besides the great choices of restaurants, the tour is paced so that you learn a lot about the history and customs of the people along the way. Yammy was fun and educational and we thoroughly enjoyed the tour. It was difficult to choose our favorite stop: between the wonton noodle soup, and the roast pork(with the tour of the kitchen) and the Dim Sum, It was a great day and highly recommended!

Yummy, educational and fun!. My friend and I took the foodie Central & Sheung Wan tour in early December.Lillian was very informative and charming. As we sampled delicious specialties from family run food establishments, Lillian explained the history of the neighborhoods as well as the food.We were so full after the tour we had to cancel our dinner plans!!!It was a very enjoyable experience and one of the highlights of our trip.

Highlight of our week in Hong Kong. Our Foodie Tour of Sham Shui Po was a great introduction to the culture, architecture, history and cuisine of a part of the city we never would have got to otherwise. Fiona our friendly guide was professional, informative, enthusiastic and so warm; a great host. It was an authentic taste of Hong Kong. Special thanks to Fiona.

Great Food & Informational Tour. Did the Sheung Wan & Central food tour with Ed and Yammy, who were both great hosts. Although Hong Kong isn't foreign to me and I've done some research on my own on great places to eat, this tour further helped to add a few more places into my must-eat places for my future Hong Kong trips. Loved every single stops that we made, but I still found the portions a bit too large for the wonton noodles (first stop) and roasted meat (second stop). Discovered a gem of a place at the preserved fruit shop. Even dim sum was excellent, which doesn't lose out to Tim Ho Wan's Sham Sui Po outlet that has 1 Michelin Star (I even went back to the dim sum place the very next day for brekkie!)!!!Along the tour, history of the places that we walked along were shared, which added perspectives to the whole tour. Am looking forward to the other 2 tours they offer and will take them up when my schedule permits in my future Hong Kong trips.
Tai Po Market Delicious journey. Did the the Tai Po Market tour with Silvana, expertly done and had a great time, highly recommended!

Central & Sheung Wan Foodie Tour. We just had the best experience with this tour. The group was happy and we had a lot of fun. The girls who guided us were very knowledgeable, kind and helpful and always ready to answer questions. All six places visited had a story but really knocked out by Dim Sum Square. Highly recommend this tour.

Central and Sheung Wan Tour. These guys offer three different tours. We ended up on the Central and Sheung Wan tour, which is basically the introductory tour into some classics that don't get too crazy, because the more adventurous ones were booked up / didn't fit with our dates.I have to say, whilst most of things we tried we'd had before in some variant or another, in every single case the versions on this tour were better. So if you're looking for quality, these guys know some good spots. Tasty.

Foodie Tour - a must do in Hong Kong. What an interesting 3 hours! Our guide, Fiona was a fountain of knowledge and gave us a great introduction to Hong Kong and its culinary delights. As long as you are a bit adventurous and have a good appetite, you will enjoy the tour. A camera and good walking shoes a must.

Great guide, good food but timing a bit misleading. This was a really good tour and took us to eateries we would not have found on our own. The guide's knowledge of Hong Kong and the food scene was excellent. However the timing was misleading, with he whole tour taking longer than the 3- 3,1/2 hours advertised, this resulted in us missing out on 2 of the 4 eateries, which was really disappointing. I would advise any first time visitor to HK to do this tour when they first arrive, so that you can use your new found food knowledge during the rest of your stay.
Amazing. I did the Sham Shui Po Tour with Fiona. Fiona was great, the food was great and the tour was insightful and fun. I would recommend this tour to anyone.

Awesome. Wife and I did the central tour with Silvana. She was fantastic - approachable, smart, and genuine. The food was awesome and plentiful. In general the tour was very informative and helped orient us with the central area of HK.

Foodie Tours...a great way to get know a new city!. I did the Sham Shui Po Foodie Tour about a week ago. Fiona was our guide and I cannot say enough good things about her and the tour. I was touring the city on my own and there were two other people on this foodie tour. I wish I would have done this earlier in my visit as it was a great learning experience and some of the things I learned both about the food and culture would have benefited the rest of my trip. I highly recommend participating in one of these tours if you are new to Hong Kong.

Tai po market tour. I did the Tai Po market tour, as I've already done the other 2 - I live in HK and am British, I recommend this to all my visitors as it shows a really good mix of culture, history and food. The Tai Po tour is the most adventurous we've done, we actually ate snake and the chef got a live snake out of the back for us to see. It's an area I wouldn't have been able to visit in my own and although I've been to tonnes of Chinese restaurants I've never had things like the black sesame soup. I think the Central tour is good for first timers in HK, Sham Shu Po for those who want a bit more off the beaten track and Tai Po possibly for residents or those who really want to eat a snack! The tour guides are always great and the information they give is spot on!

Great experience. This was my first food tour and it was very fun and interesting. I have lived in Asia 10 years and still we learned something new on this tour. Our guide, Carol, was very knowledgable and told us little stories and historical facts about buildings and about Kowloon as we walked from restaurant to restaurant. I also tried many new foods and learned about the way they are prepared. Our group ended up laughing a lot and we just had a wonderful evening. I would definitely do this tour again and recommend it to others.

Fun and delicious . Really enjoyed this tour, highly recommend. Tour guide Silvana was knowledgeable and charming, food delicious. A great selection of Cantonese classics, very interesting guided walk. Children 10 and 12 loved it.

Fabulous tour a must do when visiting Hong Kong! . Fabulous tour! My husband and I took this tour and would definitely recommend it. Not only did we try amazing food but our guide Lillian gave us a great insight into the past and present happenings of the city - we really learnt so much from Lillian. Didn't need dinner after all the delicious food! This tour was the highlight of our week in Hong Kong, big thanks to Lillian for making it so fun (we went back the next day to one of the shops for more egg tarts they were soooo good!)

OMG what a MUST! Hidden Gem.. We chose this tour from the reviews on here, and wasn't disappointed at all. What an awesome tour, everything included, and the finer details covered everything. My husband who has travelled to HK many times did not know about the toilets at the MRT or explore this area.Our group was small just the two of us, and we were lucky enough to have Fiona who was our guide.I don't think we would have have come into this area without someone showing us or on a recommendation.The first stop, Mmmm Pineapple Bun, OMG, this was so tasty. I don't drink Tea but I had a mouthful...Rice Rolls, mmmmm so tasty and full of flavour, this is a must to try...Now the Tofu Dessert, this is something I would def not go for, but was very pleasantly surprised at how wonderful it is.Braised Goose - Yum just like duck, but leaner I think.Pork knuckle was different to taste by dipping it into vinegar.The cookies were very tasty.Egg Noodles - I had the mushroom ones ... Best mushrooms ever.Loved the tasting, the places were right up our ally, we really enjoyed Fiona's local knowledge and her experiences of HK, she is a credit to your company.We will do another tour when back in HK.

A must in Hong Kong. The smartest and fastest way to learn about Hong Kong. The tour is more than tasting food. We had a chance to see the back store of most restaurants we stopped at, eat and talk with locals while learning about Hong Kong. Fiona was a fantastic guide. Excellent English, great knowledge and so enthused on teaching us about HK and its food that her alone makes the experience worthwhile. If I would have known it would be that great, I would have booked more tours with them.

Great food, great tour. My mom and I took the Central and Sheung Wan tour with Cliff. We had an amazing time on our tour eating great food. Learned a lot about the neighborhood and history. I enjoyed all the food and Cliff was a great guide.Friendly and filled with information. He calmly handled three of our tour mates arriving very late and didn't make us wait around for them, but was in contact with them and able to tell them where to meet us.

Sham Shui Po foodie tour - great way to taste and learn. We recently did the Sham Shui Po tour with Fiona from Hong Kong Foodie Tours. What a wonderful way to not only taste some traditional/local foods, but also learn about the local area, history, culture and food. Fiona was a bright, energetic , young guide who was knowledgable and enthusiastic as she guided our group of 6 through the streets and food tasting experiences. Didn't need to eat for a while after this experience either!
Awesome. Cliff was a fantastic guide! The tour was so much more than just food- history, culture, trends. Highly recommended

The Best!. Stella Chan did an incredible job as our guide on this tour. She took the time to get to know us and our taste so we had the most fabulous tour thanks to her. Dumplings were scrumptious and I have never tasted how good they can be. Her explanations were professional and informative. This tour I would highly recommend so you can get a taste of real Hong Kong delicacies. So good trying different eating establishments and being a local.

Yummy and interesting. If you're worried about eating Chinese food you should definitely go on one of these tours, as it will put your mind at ease and open up a whole new world.We did the Central and Sheung Wan tour, and it was really interesting our guide was very informative and he did take you to places you would normally have walked past. Highlights for us were the roast meats, wontons and sugar cane juice. Not so sure about the Chinese dried fruits!!Good value for money, and would recommend.

Central and Sheung Wan tour, Oct. 26. Lilian took the group on an excellent tour. She gave us not jst the history of the 6 food places we went to, but of historical sights, buildings, and streets along the way.

Better than expected. I booked this tour expecting to try some food with a guide. I am allergic to shellfish and don't read Chinese. So some guidance was a great way to start my trip to HK. The tour started on time at 2:15 and our guide, Sylvana, was amazing. A native of HK, she spoke about HK development as it pertains to the markets, spoke a lot about the restaurants we went to and explained the history of the streets and neighborhoods we walked through. Got so much more out of this trip than I had anticipated. They can accommodate many food preferences and allergies. Highly recommend it.

Food and Walking Tour. We went on the morning tour round Sham Shui Po with Fiona. A combination of food, walking and hearing nuggets of history or interesting facts about a city is one of our favourite ways to do a food tour. Also having a small group meant we could ask lots of questions, and easily be able to see much of the food we ate being made.We also really appreciated the wide variety of food that we tried, we’d never have found these things without a local taking us there. It was a mix of savoury and sweet, including a breakfast pineapple bun to a lovely soya dessert with ginger. Fiona was good company to spend the morning with! We'd definitely recommend this trip!

Wonderful food tour. Had a wonderful time on this tour and with the great host Lillian :) We really enjoyed the variety of foods on offer with this tour (wonton noodle soup, BBQ pork, fresh juice, traditional sweets, dumplings & egg tarts). Lillian was a great host, providing us with lots of info about what we were eating and the history behind the establishment we were at. On the whole a great experience in Hong Kong

Very nice tour. Lillian did a great job. Very informative and nice variety. Good amount of walking and history. Food was tasty. It would be nice if more beverages were included (either water, wine, or beer).

Hong Kong Par Excelance. We've enjoyed food tours in many parts of the world but this Central and Sheung Wan Foodie Tour led by Lillian this afternoon was a most wonderful experience. Lillian took us to 6 delightful eating experiences that found us struggling for more space in our tummies for the delicious offerings that were presented to us. To think that this was the only rewarding part of our time with Lillian would be to do her a great injustice. Firstly, after introducing herself to us, she asked each of the 12 of us to introduce ourselves to the Group. From then on, Lillian addressed each of us by name - her memory was phenomenal. That was not all that was amazing though as, for the next 3.5 hours, Lillian introduced us to the history of the regions we visited revealing an amazing knowledge and the true skill of a great story teller. Both Lillian and the Tour were outstanding and I would happily recommend this adventure to anyone interested in great food and the lesser known history of the old Hong Kong.

A great way to see the city oh and eat some food. There were some panicked phone calls to us as the tour group was about to leave, however we were right on time so that was a little unsettling to start. But the trip around tasting the different foods was great. I'm intolerant to fish and had explained this however was fed prawn dim sims in a stock I later discovered was fish. I quickly stopped eating and felt queezy for the rest of the tour so if you've actual allergies be very very clear about it. Otherwise it was great to see the city and have some history of it explained by a local. Would definitely recommend!!!

Amazing!. Our guide Fiona was awesome. Super fun and friendly. The food was a perfect balance of options. I loved the mushroom noodles!! A great way to spend a morning. Highly recommend. Would give 10 starts!!

Great tour of a real Hong Kong neighborhood, highly recommended!. Our tour of Sham Shiu Po provided a great look into a working class neighborhood. Beyond the local food, there was an excellent background on the history, current life, architecture, and economy. Our guide, Fiona, was enthusiastic, knowledgable, and happy to answer any questions. The food was great, also.

Great Tour Guide. Silvanna took us on a wonderful tour through many eateries in Hong Kong. The restaurants chosen were unique to Hong Kong Island and served delicious food. We learned more about Hong Kong through the eyes of a native Hongkonger. Silvanna answered any questions we had with ease.

Food galore. We went on the central and Sheung wan tour with Silvana and it was Amazing! The local more traditional foods such as bbq pork, wonton noodles and dim sum was the best food I have ever tasted. Silvana is very knowledgable about Hong Kong history as well as the local area. Lots of walking which was great because it helps digest all the food from last meal ready for the next one!! The tour only works with restaurants that are family owned and run which helps keep the local traditions which are fast disappearing due to greedy development. Highly recommend one of these tours whilst in Hong Kong.

Great tour, highly recommended!. We took the Sham Shui Po Foodie Tour, and I highly recommend it. It took us away from the tourist sites to local restaurants and markets and introduced us to local delicious food and the cultural background. I wish we would have time to take another of their tours. The guide was excellent, and the accommodation of vegetarians was superb.

Well done!. Took the tour with Ed and about 10 people total. Toured neighbourhoods that I would never have seen if not for tour. Ed was very knowledgable about all things Hong Kong and paced our tour very nicely. Food was excellent and favourites were noodle soup, bbq pork and rice, dim sum and egg tart. Bring an appetite because you will not go hungry. Definitely a must!

So worth it!!!. You get to walk through the neighborhoods of the restaurants you get to taste. You get a bit of culture, history and architecture along with really tasty food! Our guide was great too!

Foodie tour in Hong Kong. We participated in the "Sham Shui Po Foodie Tour", and had a great experience. Our guide was Fiona, and she focused on the food, the neighborhood, and the history. We were part of a group of eight including people from Canada, Australia, and the US. The experience was excellent, the guide was excellent, and the food ranged from good to excellent.

Sham Sui Po Tour - Delicious and Fun. I took the Sham Sui Po tour on 5 September 2015. It started at 9:15 a.m., perfectly on-time. Our guide was Fiona.Our guide was fun, easy to understand, very knowledgable, always energetic, and quickly developed a good rapport with the rest of the group.Before the start of the tour, our guide gave us a map with descriptions of the food on order, water and wipes. We arrived at 9:00. There was a briefing for about 10 minutes, and then the tour began. It ended at 12:40. You may want to bring your own water. Most of the places we visited had existed for several decades, and had been operated throughout generations of the same family. The food is thus considered part of HK history.Throughout the tour, in between stops, we were regaled with an oral history of HK and the area. As well as the present conditions. We learned about why the pawnshops are the way they are, the cages for rent, we stopped at a knife maker's shop. We learned how to stand beside the table of people eating to pressure them to finish, as is supposedly the HK way.We also learned that bumping into people is as easy as eating rice.Shopping is discouraged to keep the group moving, but there is time for reasonable purchases the don't take much thinking (cellphone cases, adaptors, mooncakes). This might depend on your group though.This tour is great value for money. The missing star is because I'm a Filipino, and we chose the Sham Sui Po tour in part because of the schedule (foodie tour first thing in the morning, and on an empty stomach!), but also because they were offering more "traditional" HK fare. However, a lot of the food was easily accessible in our China Town. Maybe that's not fair, but regardless, we were looking for something more exotic, that we couldn't get elsewhere.The food was absolutely fantastic however, despite the above.1st Stop Pineapple Bun and Milk Tea - You get the buns fresh from the oven. Those who know what this means know that this means heaven. I loved the milk tea, but my companions (from Canada, Australia, and there were two Americans) seemed not to enjoy it too much, as it wasn't as sweet as what's normally available commercially. You can add sugar though.This place is supposedly closed for I think a month for renovation, so up to October.2nd Stop Rice Rolls. My favourite. The sauce is the essence.3rd Stop Soybean milk. There is a cold drink and warm soup option.4rd Stop Braised Goose. Duck and Goose No rice, sadly.5th Stop Walnut Cookies. Sadly, this was just bought from a store. It was yummy, but we were full at this point. Not what we were expecting.6th Stop Egg Noodles w/ Shrimp Roe. This was the favourite of the rest of my tour group, and my second favourite. Fantastic! We arrived )as calculated, allegedly) right at 12:30, as the restaurant opened, and it was full in 5 minutes. Real local fare.Anyway, it's worth it. We wanted to do just one tourist-y thing in HK and shop the rest of the time, and we were not disappointed.P.S. Good shopping around the area too. You can find really local stuff, not just the ladies market stuff manufactured for tourists (although you'll find this there too). I'll try to upload pictures later, if TA will allow me to.

Excellent, fun guide. Wonderful (and not weird) food.. Don't worry. You won't get any chicken feet on this tour. Cliff, our tour guide, was a fun, knowledgeable and sincere guide who took us to hidden spots - and made sure that all dietary restrictions were respected. The food was exquisite - and served in local joints that I normally wouldn't wander into... especially those with various meats (and their heads) hanging in the windows. A wonderful way to get to know the real Hong Kong. Thank you!

Fantastic tour guides, fantastic food and fantastic sights! . I loved loved loved this tour! I my mouth is still watering for the culinary delights that we had on the tour. Make sure you don't eat before you go! Our 2 tour guides were amazing and full of an array of local knowledge which improved my holiday 100%! Make sure you wear flat comfy shoes as there is a fair bit of waking especially up hills and stairs. Fantastic and wonderful experience!
Great experience in food tasting. We enjoyed much full local food with an amazing selection of dishes. The staffs were lovely, friendly and do efficient.

The first tour you do!. My wife and I had a wonderful introduction to Cantonese cuisine, the places to go and the etiquette, history and variety of Hong Kong food. Ed was our guide who's knowledge, passion and insight helped us quickly understand this fascinating culture via its food. I only wish we had done this first.

Food and Walking Tour Combined!. Great change of pace to my trip to Hong Kong. Silvana our guide was great and very much seemed to love sharing the food of Hong Kong with travelers. She also provided a walking tour of the area, pointing out places of interest and again seem to actually enjoy her job. I ended up going back to one of the places twice more during my stay! Any foodie will enjoy this fun day out!

Great Tai Po food tour in Hong Kong!. Had a really great tour with Silvana at HK Foodie Tours. Travelling to HK often, I have taken all of their previous tours and loved them, am also familiar with asian cuisine, so was really excited about a more unique tour of HK and experiencing different dishes. Visited six eateries:- Not a lover of rice rolls, but the ones we tried were DELICIOUS. Suggest everyone order different rolls and share as you experience more - we had liver, pork and scallops!- Visited a roast goose restaurant: most succulent duck ever. Particularly loved the plum sauce!- Loved the Chinese sweet store! The owners were really friendly and accommodating and couldn't get enough of their nut mixtures. Also saw how they made other candies (ginger sweets) which was great.- The snake store was a unique experience and would highly recommend it! Up to you if you want to taste or not (I ate the soup and it was tasty!)- Really enjoyed going to the dai pai dong above the local vegetable/meat markets. Loved the atmosphere, felt like I really was doing/eating what a local would. Lots of seafood here, and delicous, too! Crab was goooooood!- Ended tour at a dessert place and had some almond 'soup'. Not so much of a dessert person, but surprisingly yummy. Make sure you don't eat too much before starting the tour - you'll be full by the end of it!Places visited:One of the reason why I LOVE going one these tour is you also learn about the local area, not just experience the delicious food! I particularly loved exploring Tai Po, an area I'd never been to before and it didn't disappoint. (Will return to explore further!)Visited a railway museum along the way which was quite interesting. The architecture was really pretty and a very pleasant quiet place away from the hustle and bustle of Tai Po. Walking through Tai Po Market was amazing, too! I adore visiting markets, and I loved all the different stalls (seem to have more variety) Tai Po offered. Nestled in between it all, there was a beautiful little temple we visited - incense, drums, statues - fantastic.Silvana was a fantastic tour guide, very knowledgeable and friendly. Great group, too, one couple in particular were hilarious and we have stayed in touch!Highly recommend HK Foodie Tai Po tour to friends looking for a more unique culinary/cultural experience - definitely no pork buns or custard tarts on this tour!

Great experience. We visited 6 different venues during this tour. While we did not eat a lot at any one, by the end of the tour we were definitely full. Part of the appeal is not knowing where you are going in advance, so I son't give too much away, but suffice it to say that we sampled many different types of local food. The tour sticks to local, family owned businesses that do not necessarily cater to tourists, this was clearly evident by the menus not being written in any other language other than Chinese. As could be expected, with a different set of tastes, our group of 4 did not like ALL of the food choices, but we all liked MOST of the choices :)Our guide Cliff was very knowledgeable, and mixed in a fair share of history and general local culture as we wandered through Hong Kong.

Fantastic food & fantastic tour guide. Attended the Central tour with tour guide Cliff who was absolutely amazing. His mix of humour, history and knowledge of food made it an extremely enjoyable experience. We visited 6 different places, and even though one of the venues did not sit well on our tastebuds, it was still great for a cultural experience.Another great aspect of the tour was mixing with the other tour participants, who ranged from a hilarious young Australian couple, to a very funny American family of four!I would definitely recommend this tour to anyone visiting Hong Kong.

Fiona + Sham Shui Po Foodie Tour = Delightful + Delicious!. I joined a small group for a wonderful foodie tour of Sham Shui Po with the delightful Fiona as our guide. I love the idea of a breakfast food tour, especially as it went all the way through to lunch time. The melt-in-the-mouth tofu with ginger sauce was my favourite, but it was all delicious and interesting. As a vegetarian, I appreciated that Fiona made sure I wasn't left out when we went to places for meat-based tastings. And not only did we get to try several Hong Kong specialities, but we were also treated to a lot of stories of local history and culture. Very highly recommended!

Great insight into Hong Kong food culture. Did the Central Hong Kong Foodie tour last week with EXCELLENT guide Ed. He was friendly, informative and funny! More than just a food tour, there's a whole lot of history thrown in along the way as you wander the streets from restaurant to restaurant. I highly recommend taking this foodie tour when in Hong Kong. Thanks so much Ed!

Excellent added value foodie tour. I went on the Sham Shui Po foodie tour. Our tour guide was Fiona - a very energetic lady who was keen and genuinely eager to share with us cultural tidbits about Sham Shui Po and Hong Kong.They give you a leaflet at the start of the tour showing the places that will be visited on the tour and what will be tasted at the different venues. The leaflet also has the addresses of other recommended eateries so you can visit them and the places visited during the tour in your own time if you so wish. I went back to the bakery where we tasted some cookies as I wanted to try the wife cake which was excellent.We went to six different eateries. The most popular dishes among the group I was in was the roast goose and tofu pudding. The tofu pudding was soft and the ginger syrup which you could pour on top was simply divine - it had just the right blend of sweetness and fire to it.It was a bit pricey for street food but the added value of the tour was well worth the price in my opinion - you get to eat at traditional eateries without the staff hurrying you on and without having to deal with any communication problems as a result of not speaking any Cantonese, you get to meet new people, you get to visit other areas of interest in Sham Shui Po which aren't food-related (we went to a beads store and a knife shop).

Great tour offering more than just food tasting. This was excellent value for money and Silvana, the tour guide was very knowledgeable about Central and Sheung Wan Districts as well as typical Hong Kong food. The tour is well balanced and gave us an opportunity to try all kinds of dishes, from noodles and roast meat to typical dim sum served with pu-erh tea, plus pastries, sweets and sugar cane juice. There were several people with specific dietary requirements in the group and Silvana took time to understand what their needs were and then made sure that there were alternatives available at each food destination.

Great Tour. My husband and I were welcomed by Fiona our very informative guide and off we went. Our first stop was for Pineapple buns and milk tea. Of the 6 in the party I was probably the only one that didn't like the tea, but the bun was delicious. Next to a tiny restaurant specialising in rice rolls ok but we prepared ours with filling. A tour of the area and different shops was very interesting and our stop at a shop that held exclusively dried goods was particularly enlightening. There was a shop selling snake stew and a restaurant where we enjoyed shrimp egg noodles. We really recommend this tour.

Best food tour in HK!. We live in Hong Kong and were given this food tour as a Christmas present. It was such a fun afternoon going to places we had never been to before! Ed was an amazing guide! He was super friendly and had so much energy even in the heat! I learned many interesting facts about Hong Kong. We went on the Central & Sheung Wan Foodie tour. My favorites were the dim sum and the egg tarts. I did find the preserved fruit store very interesting and fun as well! I highly recommend this for tourists and local people! It is a great way to learn more about Hong Kong!

Great fun and food!. My husband and I and our 2 daughters went on the Sheung Wan Foodie Tour during our recent visit to Hong Kong to experience some authentic traditional food. We were part of a small group and visited a number of places where we sampled food including wonton noodle soup, BBQ pork and rice, preserved fruits, sugar cane juice, Yum Cha (char sui bao, har gao, spring rolls) and custard tarts. There was more than enough food and although we had eaten many of these foods before, we found it very interesting to visit the local markets and eateries. We enjoyed the commentary which we found fascinating. Our tour guide was very friendly, knowledgeable and informative and we also enjoyed getting to know some of the other people on the tour. Highly recommended

Great experience!. I would highly recommend the Hong Kong Foodie Tour. We thoroughly enjoyed the experience. We went on the central and sheung wan tour. The shrimp dumplings and BBQ pork were excellent. We went back to the same dim sum restaurant during our stay, because I had to have it again! We also loved the hot eff custards. We went back to the egg custard place two more times before we left Hong Kong.This should be everyone's first stop in Hong Kong to acquaint themselves with the food culture! They can then enjoy going back to some of these authentic eats before they leave!

Best way to see and taste Hong Kong!. My partner and I booked the Central and Sheung Wan tour when we visited late last month. It was easily the highlight of our city adventure!! The food was phenomenal and we even went back to a few places in the days after the tour. You learn about the culture and history as well, so good! One of the other posts recommended you do it on the first day and I second that. It gives you a great idea of the city and helps to get used to Chinese restaurants with no obvious English. Highly recommend this tour!!

Highly Recommend. We loved this tour and it was the highlight of our trip. The food was very memorable and the best we tasted in Hong Kong. Our guide was very knowledgeable, friendly, punctual and had a real insight into the local area and food. It wasn't just about the food but also a tour of the local area.

Really, Really Enjoyed, Both the Food, and the Extensive Info. Took the Central tour a few weeks ago in June 2015. Sylvana (SP?) was our guide. She was fantastic! We've been on a lot of food tours in a lot of cities, and she was one of the best.The food was delicious (esp. the roast pork and the shrimp wanton noodle soup) and the walk was great - just the right length.But what was also great was that our tour guide had tons of additional information about Hong Kong. In addition to her talks at various stops along the way, she was able to answer and question we had about life, culture, and history, and she happily gave us really complete answers to our questions.Highly recommended!

Central and Sheung Wan Foodie Tour. Would highly recommend this tour - Lillian our tour guide was terrific, very informative and lots of fun. The food was delicious (don't eat before hand), and plentiful. Great combination of history, culture and food. Give it a try, you won't be disappointed.

Tai Po Market foodie tour - fascinating tour for those who who want to know more!. Amazing tour of local delicacies in Tai Po that we would never have been brave enough to try on our own during our 4 days in Hong Kong. It was especially interesting to learn about the culture, customs and food of this area of the New Territories and contrast this with our experiences and food of the "touristy" spots we had already visited. Silvana, our enthusiastic guide was so passionate about sharing her knowledge of the foods' source, how it is specially hand prepared, its medicinal qualities, local customs, background about the restaurants, etc. Lots of delicious freshly prepared food (included in the tour price) and you can see how it is prepared in the restaurants - the tour is very well planned and researched - we can't recommend the Tai Po foodie tour enough! Don't miss this one!

The highlight of our trip to Hong Kong. Our Hong Kong foodie tour of Central and Shueng Wan was among the highlights not only of out trip to Honk Kong but of our entire two week journey through Asia. Our guide (Silvanna) was exceptional. The food was excellent (and in very generous portions) and they tour was very well planned and organized. The restaurants are all mom-and-pops and are very well chosen. Its the perfect mix of food, culture and history and a fabulous way to experience local food and explore Hong Kong's diverse neighborhoods. Highly, highly recommended.

Food was great!. We did Central 2pm food tour. The guide was very knowledgeable and spoke excellent English. The food we tried was delicious and servings large. Dont eat before hand you will never fit it all in.We enjoyed the food part of the tour but the tour also included a large proportion of history whichwe were unaware of. Its worth doing but not a "Must Do" in my opinion

Foodie Tour Gives Great Insight. We did the morning tour of Sham Shui Po. The total tour group was 7 and we were hosted by a young lady who had excellent English.We visited six food establishments many of which we would not have been game to try if we were travelling independently. But with the insights and knowledge provided by our guide it was an easy and enlightening experience.The walking part of the tour is easy in fact it is more like a stroll as took in the delights of the wide variety of food types. This covered steamed buns & milk tea, rice rolls, soy milk/pudding, braised goose, HK cookies & specialty noodles. The winner was definitely the soy desert with the ginger syrup ..... mmmmm ! The food portions are small so it's ok to have a light breakfast before starting.Of great interest was the historical and cultural insights that were provided as we walked round and dined. We also visited several other local businesses between food stops which added greatly to the insights provided.A good tour and well worth doing.

AMAZING Hotel. I took this tour recently, our guide was Sylvanna. She was amazing, super nice and her english was perfect. All I have to say is DO IT. If you really enjoy good food and don't know where to go this is the right thing to do.

Tai Po Market Foodie Tour!. Finally made my way back to HK again after 3 years, since I had such a good experience with the Central and Sheung Wan Foodie Tour last time, I was excited and looking forward to this new foodie tour in Tai Po before even I was back. What I looked forward to was not just the tasty local food I'm going to try, but this new tour is going to take me to New Territories! That's very exciting!MTR is so convenient that there's no trouble just to follow the system map and got myself to Tai Po station. The station wasn't that huge neither and I spotted my tour guide before I was even out of the gate.During the tour I got to try handmade steam rice rolls with different fillings (BBQ pork being my favorite), juicy roast goose (definitely going back!), handmade Chinese candies (tried ginger candy, pumpkin seeds & my favorite peanuts candy!), snake soup (very exotic but it really just taste like chicken and the soup actually taste quite good), fresh local seafood and Chinese desserts.Such an exciting new tour to show me more special local food, and also it's nice to have a friendly tour guide to show me a different area of HK (always wonder what's there in New Territories). Highly recommend for anyone who look to try more local food while adventuring into the New Territories!!

Learn to eat like a local. Can't say enough good things about the Sham Shui Po Foodie Tour! Took this tour on May 29th with Fiona and she did a great job. You will be taken to 6 small local restaurants that you would never find on your own that do a great job or representing authentic Hong Kong cuisine. In addition to that our guide gave us great insight into the area we were touring and the history of how it had developed. Really a cool way to walk around, sample some amazing food and learn about an area of town that otherwise most tourists probably wouldn't go to.

Great local insight. We took the Sham Shui Po tour with Fiona - in short... do it!The tour was an amazing "foot in the door" to local, traditional foods in a very interesting neighbourhood. Fiona was fantastic - she is very engaging, bright and energetic.We were with our 10 and 12 year old daughters, and they had a great time. The food is adventurous but certainly not over the top bizarre. The restaurants and shops were all handpicked for their quality and cleanliness.I highly recommend this tour if you're on a short stop or extended stay in Hong Kong.

Visiting from Oz. Had an amazing experience with Ed on our Foodie Tour today. We visited authentic Hong Kong restaurants and the hospitality was lovely as they were all family run. Ed had great knowledge and showed us not only great food but interesting sights around Hong Kong Central and Sheung Wan. Great experience

Way cool tour, great food a bonus!. Really glad we did this tour on the first day of our 8 day visit, can't wait to re-visit a couple of the food stops as well as the other recommendations we got on the tour. And we learned heaps about Hong Kong and the neigjborhoods and food places we visited. The food wasn't paricularly adventurous, but it was excellent and it was clear that the itinerary was really well thought out. Ed, our guide was a real highlight - a really nice and entertaining dude, and he went out of his way to give advice to members of our group (about anything we asked). Highly recommended!

Excellent Food Tour!. My wife and I thoroughly enjoyed this food tour through the streets of Hong Kong! Our tour guide was very knowledgeable and spoke excellent English! The food at each stop was delicious, plentiful and fresh! It was a very interesting and enjoyable tour which we would highly recommend! Tip - be prepared to do some walking (not a lot) and take an umbrella.

Excellent Value. I wholeheartedly agree with many others as to the interesting and yummy places we visited. What I would also like to point out is that we (My wife, 20 year old daughter and I from Sydney) also re-visited two or three of the food places independently over the next three days - and had wonderful, authentic, modestly priced meals. We also revisited some of the areas and appreciated knowing the culture and history behind them - my daughter particularly enjoyed exploring the Urban Cool of some Sheung Wan areas later on.

No better way to start your visit to Hong Kong. We spent the most stunning afternoon walking round the Central & Sheung Wan areas hosted by Lilian, who was so enthusiastic and informative, one could not have imagined a better guide for the afternoon. The balance of the afternoon was perfect, starting with wonton noodle soup, followed by bar-b-que meats (with visits to the kitchens in both). The quality of the food was outstanding, and being quite hungry to start with is a bonus! This was followed by a tour of the wet market, a try of (tooth rottingly sweet) sugar cane juice and dried and preserved fruits. The walk through the back street between the two districts was fascinating and built up the appetite for the last restaurant visit, dim sum. The crispy pork buns were something to behold and eat. The final piece de resistance were the most delicious custard tarts fresh out of the oven. One word of advice for newbies, you will probably want to spend the morning doing something around Hong Kong..... If you are away from the metro station beware, travel takes much longer then you realise, and you will not want to be late for this afternoon treat.

Sham Shui Po - amazing!. Silvana was a fantastic guide to this fascinating part of Hong Kong. Visited family owned cafes and restaurants in a part of the city I couldn't have even begun to scratch the surface of. Ate loads of delicious things that I also wouldn't have found by myself.

Sham Shui Po Tour. We have just completed this tour and it was a wonderful experience . We have been to HK many times but not to this area. The tour is about the history of the area as well as lots of great food to eat along the way . Experiencing many family run food businesses was a highlight and learning about the history of these places . Our guide was very knowledgeable and helpful . Would recommend this tour most highly

Excellent food tour of HK!. I really enjoyed this food tour of Hong Kong and would highly recommend it as a great way to taste excellent food and learn about culture, history and architecture along the way. I found the food stops to be very well considered - 3 towards the start of the tour (which for me, smallish eater) were a late lunch, and 3 towards the end which were an early dinner. I enjoyed all of the 6 very much - they were varied, authentic and high quality. There were also many other sights pointed out in between the food stops. I had spent the morning walking around the same area including past some of the places that we later went on the tour - I had completely missed them and their significance and got so much more out of the area having been on the tour. Very good activity for me as a single traveller (or for groups). Thanks very much to our guide Sylvia for a great tour.

Great tour. I did the breakfast/lunch Sham Shui Po tour. It was a great tour! We had many foods that I had never had before. We went to six places on the tour. Most of them were really great tasting and all were very cultural. It was cool to go to some local places and discover local foods that I wouldn't known about. The price was good, and our tour guide Fiona was great! She was very vibrant, knowledgeable, and entertaining! She told us a lot about the foods, local history of the region, and other little facts and tid-bits. She also answered many questions that we had about Hong Kong. I want to try the afternoon tour next!

Great food, best way to see the city.. Our guide, Lillian, was a pleasure to spend time with. Not only was she knowledgeable about the food and establishments we visited, she also has a great understanding on Hong Kong as a city, as well as the cultural backgrounds of all who live there. The food was all delicious and the portions were big, considering we visited 6 different places. The tour was set at a good pace and we never felt rushed nor pressured to buy anything further from each place. I wish I could have followed our footsteps to taste all the food a second time!

Great food tour. Great tour with a knowledgeable local guide who talks perfect English. Revisited one of the places two days later and we had to queue to get in, The bonus of being on the tour is they are expecting you so they have seats ready and you walk straight in!Recommend doing the tour at the start of your holiday so you learn your way around a bit, some local etiquette as well as some fantastic places to dine.

Four hours of Fun, Food and Facts - a must do!. We did the Central and Sheung Wan Foodie tour as we were staying on Hong Kong Island in Wan Chai. As a family of four with 2 daughters aged 13yrs & 11yrs we thought it would be a good family thing to do and all of us left the tour feeling it was one of the best things we did in Hong Kong because it was something we all enjoyed. We all chose something to do in Hong Kong and my 11yr old found this tour online and chose it as her 'thing to do' and she got a pat on the back for that. I recommend doing the tour at the beginning of the trip (we did it day 2 of a 7 day trip)as you will probably want to go back to some of the eateries. We went back to the restaurant serving BBQ pork and rice and also went back for the egg tarts which we loved but we all love custard and shortbread so we were all craving them! Don't eat too much before the tour you will be full at the end and it was very hot (28 degrees) so take a backpack with extra water and some moist towelettes or antibacterial gel for your hands.Lillian was our tour guide and she was very informative and had a lovely personality, she was fantastic. We had some travel bloggers on our tour and they seemed to enjoy the tour, it's a great thing to do to introduce you to Hong Kong and taste some of the local food!OTHER THINGS TO DO IN HONG KONG..... take the #260 bus to Stanley Markets and make sure you sit at the top of the double decker bus, the coastal drive is fantastic and a little hair raising! The shopping is o.k at Stanley it's the surroundings that are the highlight and the grocery store there is great to hunt down different local foods and try some durian! (not a fan lol)Do a day trip to Macau 1 hour on the turbo jet each way and make sure you see the House of Dancing Water it's expensive but so worth it a highlight of our trip approx. $600 NZD for our family but would go again in a heartbeat, it's like cirque du soleil on crack! Don't leave without seeing it!!!! The Venetian is also amazing, having been to Vegas this is bigger than Vegas with 3 gondola canals and the shopping is also good at the Venetian. We had a crazy gondola ride with an Italian guy, he had locals following him (groupies) he was funny and entertaining wish I could list his name he had us all laughing and was a fantastic singer singing frozen 'let it go' for our daughters. Have fun in Hong Kong.

Six tastes with stories. We had a lovely afternoon with Lillian. She was delightful, informative and very passionate about Hong Kong cultural history. We ate an amazing Wonton noodle Soup, BBQ pork, Sugar cane juice, preserved fruits, Dim sums and to top it off the delicious egg tart. In addition we visited some really interesting off beat areas on Hong Kong island and got a great insite into the local culture and history. Thank you Lillian

Food, Culture and History - what more could you want in tour?. Our tour was of the Central and Sheung Wan districts. We enjoyed fantastic food from restaurants, shops and stalls which were family owned and in some cases, there for generations.Cliff, our guide, was funny, personable and full of interesting information on the food and how it relates to Hong Kong's history and culture.We visited some of the other recommendations from the tour pamphlet and loved them all. The choice Cantonese phrases were useful also.This is a well organised tour which I would have been happy to bring my primary school aged children on (this time though it was just us adults).By the way - the food was awesome too :)

Great Choices - Revisited 2 restaurants!. Many of the reviews covered the venues and the tour itself, all of which I agree with so I won't repeat these apart from: the wonton restaurant, recommended by Michelin, made the best wonton I have ever eaten! Large dumplings, full of prawn and well seasoned with sesame oil - magnificent! Sylvana, Hong Kong born, managed to keep us interested for over 4 hours and was full of information, answering the many questions posed to her, she created a good atmosphere and had the 8 or so tourists chatting to each other as we ate food and shared experiences.What I will do however is to compare this foodie tour with another I did - the markets tour of Kowloon (Bird, flower, Temple St and fish markets). OK, both were different in objectives but the central theme must have been to inform, entertain and educate. The foodie tour excelled whereas the markets tour was a stroll along the streets by a German resident who knew her stuff but simply did not have the passion or depth of knowledge to make it matter. I am not even sure why I paid to walk along the street and markets, which I could have done myself, with the aid of a map and a little guide book. On reflection, I made an error.if you are visiting Kowloon and HKG and want to do some walking tours - I recommend you do the 2 Foodie tours covering the 2 areas and not bother with the market tour - you can do that yourself and I am sure the food tour will cover the districts far better than my experience on the market tour.

Good way to taste local life. Took the tour the last week of April 2015. I enjoyed most the food on the tour, most notably, the braised goose, the noodles with the shrimp egg powder, milk tea, the warm and soft tofu dessert, and the rice rolls. I did not like the cookies. In my opinion, they were dry and not very unique. The guides were knowledgeable about the local life, as well as the history of the area. They even discussed some contemporary issues between Hong Kongers and mainland Chinese people, but just a little bit as these issues are sensitive topics. We toured through the working class Sham Shui Po neighborhood on the red subway line--Kowloon side of HK. Personally, this is a great tour for travellers who are not accustomed to crowded Asian metropolises. I have been living on mainland China for the past the two years, so some of the information about the Sham Shui Po local markets and sights was a bit redundant for me because there are similarities to mainland Chinese markets. On the other hand, it was a great break from mainland China as Hong Kong is much cleaner and the quality of food is much higher than what I've had in major mainland Chinese cities. Whenever I eat something on the mainland I hear a nagging voice in my head saying "Are you sure you want to eat this? Eat at your own risk!" There seems to be a lack of food quality assurance and food quality regulation in China. Hong Kong feels different and I did not feel that I was taking a huge health risk when eating the food. Of course, this is entirely subjective and everyone could have a different perception. I recommend this tour because the guides will take you to local eateries that could otherwise be intimidating if you're a first-timer, especially for someone who does not speak Cantonese. Take the tour, it's worth it.

Authentic introduction to real Hong Kong. We did the Kowloon tour with Fiona and it was fantastic. We couldn't have asked for a better tour of real and Chinese HK - places to eat run by families for generations, tasty exotic treats and explorations through crazy markets and old school shops - will definitely recommend this to any guests in HK!!! Fiona is funny and full of good facts - love her!!

Great intro for first-timers. My wife and I had never been to HK and wanted some food guidance. Our guide (Lillian) was personable and knowledgeable about both the foods we tried and the areas we walked through and deserves 5 stars based on her presentation alone. Overall, I'm giving the tour 4 stars because I think it drags in the middle when it becomes more history-oriented and less food-focused. Each food shop we visited (noodle soup, dim sum, dried fruits, etc.) was interesting, but I would have preferred either an extra food stop or a rerouting to help keep the focus on food.

Such a good time. In my tour we had two guides, Fiona and Amy. Both were native and both shared so much about the food, the area, about themselves, it was like being taken around by two friends. The food they shared with us was great and they took us only to old school local places. No chains. Definitely places I would not have found on my own and if I did I might not have tried them. It was a vey cultural experience. I would do it again.

Great experience. 6 different food and drink locations over a 4 hour trip. Really interesting and great fun. Gave us the confidence to go away and try local restaurants. Our guide was really good and the whole afternoon very well organised If you are in Hong Kong for a few days you should do this tour

Pretty Delicious! Fun Experience. Did a food tour for the first time and it was a great experience. The tastings were good and the guide was very knowledgeable. Only downsides were I wish there was more food and the group of 9 was a bit big in my opinion.

Wonderful way to learn about HK. We read reviews prior and they were spot on. Our guide (Sylvana) was knowledgeable about Hong Kong food and the local area and was able to make the tour interesting in both a culinary and cultural way. The six stops are quite a bit of food but are spaced well and there is absolutely no pressure to finish everything. The restaurants are amazing and definitely ones I never would have visited (randomly) on my own. I highly recommend a tour with this outfit!

Tasty and informative, a great tour! . We went on this tour with a group of about 9 people, which was a good size. Our knowledgeable guide led us to about 6 different venues where we tasted so much delicious food. Especially the giant won ton noodles, roasted pork, mixed dim sum and Portugese custard tarts where amongst the best we tasted during our 3 week trip through China and HK. Our guide gave very interesting backround information about the dishes, preparation and culture. Although the costs of about €85 per person are a bit high in comparison to food tours we had in other countries, it was worth it because of the quality of the food, good guide and length of the tour (3.5 hours).

Amazing way to see the city.... We went on the central and sheung wan tour and were very impressed. As a tourist having a chance to eat in local restaurants which you would otherwise overlook gave a real taste of the city. Not only do you get to taste great food but our guide was knowledgable about the history and culture on Hong Kong. Thoroughly recommend.

Fantastic tour with great guide, food and information. Sylvana was our guide for the Central/Sheun Wan foodie tour and her knowledge of food and Hong Kong history was excellent. The tour is set at a good pace but does cover a fair bit of ground. There are 6 stops and are spread out well enough so you don't feel overly full too quickly.The tour is a great way to understand the different types of local food and the history behind them, as well as being able to explore some changing neighbourhoods. The food you taste is plentiful in portion size, and varies from wonton soup, cane juice to dumplings plus more! I highly recommend this tour to anyone visiting Hong Kong, no matter how long your stay is.

Well worth the admission!. If you like great local food, walking through the heart of an incredible city, learning about its culture, and meeting fun people this tour is for you.
Our tour guide Ed did an incredible job and it was the best wonton soup of our lives!
Enjoy yourself!

two thumbs up. I, my husband, and my two girls (15 & 17), took the Sham Shui Po tour last month and it was a great experience! The confirmation email from the tour company was detail and informative about where to meet, and how to get there, also what to wear and tour duration etc. The meeting location was so easy to find and the group size (total of 6) was good to be able to move around with our guide on the crowded streets in HK. This food tasting and cultural walking tour was about 4 hours, stopping at 6 tasting locations. Our guide, Fiona was friendly, knowledgable and helpful. It was very interesting to explore the older style of Hong Kong by knowing some history of the neighbourhoods and learning some fun facts about Hong Kong's cuisine, we liked going behind the scene of a Hong Kong style Cafe to check out how to make the delicious milk tea! Totally awesome and not to mention the mouth watering Food! They were all the best Chinese food we had ever tried! Also, we were provided with a brochure of food tasting and Restaurants/shops Guide, together attached with a map and some useful Cantonese Phrases, all were nice touches. Two thumbs up! We will highly recommend this tour and this company to everyone.

Happy return customer. I have done both the Sham Shi Po and the Central Sheung Wan tours on different trips to HK over the last 6 months and loved them both. They are different experiences with types of food but both were great. Both guides were excellent and full of knowledge about the local area and culture as well as the food itself. The venues we visited were friendly and welcoming and happy for photos to be taken - I always ask the restaurant staff if it's ok to take photos of them....most are happy for me to do so and give lovely big smiles. I like the small group size on the tours. Always easy to hear the guide even if you are in a busy area and plenty of opportunity to ask questions. Highly recommend BOTH these tours!!!!!!

Sham Shi Po Food Tour - great way to learn more about Hong Kong culture and cuisine.. My teenagers and I loved the Sham Shui Po food tour, because it gave us insider access to small family run restaurants and food stalls that are popular with locals, but would have been hard for us as non-Chinese speakers to navigate. The six different dishes that we sampled were unique and delicious, unusual without being intimidating to our Westernized palates. Our guide, Fiona, was smart and informative. She shared a lot of the history of the neighborhood, and demonstrated how to add the right sauces or syrups to each food selection. We highly recommend Foodie tours for those who like to get a little off the beaten tourist path.

A MUST DO If you are in Hong Kong. I did last week the Central & Sheung Wan Foodie Tour and in one word it was AMAZING. the walking tour is a perfect way eat your way through what Hong Kong has to offer, you really get a good feel of the city and the food you taste is just out of the world and you can see how they prepare the food and you learn their history. So if you are in hong Kong and you are a foodie you HAVE to do a foodie tour with Hong Kong foodie tour

see and taste the real traditional Hong Kong. There are two sides of Hong Kong. the modern and the traditional old culture.For me, you can see modern things anywhere, Shanghai, Beijing (also visited on this vacation), North America-any city. What is really interesting for a foreigner is the traditional old culture! This is a disappearing thing everywhere. I loved seeing the traditional Hong Kong, the kind that sets it apart from any other place in the world. The crowded streets with bustling merchants, the streetside stalls, the herbal stores with amazing things like dried lizards (an eye opener) was expertly narrated by our guide, Fiona, who was friendly and knowledgable. So this was a cultural journey with amazing tasting of local foods that I would not have otherwise been able to discover. At first I was afraid I would be served ingredients I would find revolting, but in the end, everything was delicious and more than palatable. We had special baked foods, special milk tea, duck, hand made noodles etc. The most interesting was pork hock and it was delicious. We did pass by a snake restaurant but snake soup was not part of the tasting tour. Don't eat breakfast, as you want to be hungry for all the food you will try. For the 4 hours I felt like I was a local and really lived the experience. Did I mention the glimpses into the kitchens arranged by the guide so we can see how the food we ate was prepared? Excellent. Be warned, to see this side of Hong Kong, which is not the most modern and pampered side of life, you will walk through crowded, sweaty, noisy streets, but IMHO, unless you have done something like this, and eaten some of these unique and traditional foods, and have had such expert local guidance, you will have missed what Hong Kong is all about. Fiona was great and was able to advise other restaurants to try more traditional cuisine in case your are staying in Hong Kong for a bit longer. Highly recommended.

So Much More Than A Food Tour. We did the Sham Shui Po tour and our guide Fiona was excellent in both knowledge and how she conducted the tour. The tour around the working class area of Sham Shui Po is a memorable experience for all the right reasons. Not only will you eat in places that westerners would not normally be seen in (although I have no doubt they would be welcomed with opened arms) but you also get to hear about the history of the area and how people are living now including the living conditions. This tour will give you the information (printed) and more importantly the confidence to go back to these places and the desire to try other eateries as well. I would have definitely took the Central tour as well but unfortunately due to Chinese New Year holidays the tour was not running during our time in Hong Kong.

Superb tour of Sham Shui Po market & local cuisine. Led by a knowledgable and personable tour guide, the four hour tour of Sham Shui Po was a favorite of the trip. The tour features a range of fare, from the well-executed items one might expect on such an itinerary (pineapple buns, braised goose) to surprises both delightful and unknown (steamed rice rolls in a delicious sauce, shimp roe on handmade noodles). Additionally, invitations to take a peek behind the scenes at cooks and chefs in action was a rare and much appreciated treat. The tour is structured so as to not linger any place too long, but with an attention to pacing that other tours could well learn from. The brochure with restaurant names, helpful phrases, a map and a list of further recommendations is a great idea and excellent resource. Our tour guide Fiona was incredibly knowledgeable and most informative about the food, neighborhood, culture, and daily life of Hong Kongers; we would very highly recommend tours with her, and this company.

Unique and first class. Whether you are visiting Hong Kong or live here, you won’t be disappointed in this tour.We took the Central and Sheung Wan tour and were super impressed. Booking and meeting the group was easy. Walking between venues i easy. We ate great local food (Wontons, dim sum, egg tarts) at interesting places. Places that you probably don’t know about if you live in Hong Kong or would never try if you are visiting. And we saw more than just restaurants and tables. We learnt about historical sites, heard the city’s amazing stories and visited Hong Kong’s unique back streets. The highlight for us was the enthusiasm and knowledge of our guide Clifford for the food, the people who cook it and the local history of Central and Sheung Wan. He made this ‘more than a food tour’. Oh don’t forget to try the sugar cane juice :-).

Fantastic tour!. My boyfriend and I just completed the food tour in central and sheung wan with Lilian as our guide and we were extremely pleased with the food we were able to eat. Lilian is a very helpful and wonderful tour guide as she provided alot of information and history about the restaurants, food and culture in Hong Kong. I would gladly go on another Hong Kong foodie tour next time!

So much more than food!. We took the Central tour with Silvana and Ed (who I believe was tagging along as a trainee, but you never would have known it). Silvana and Ed were excellent, the tour was excellent, and after we were done, I wished we had time to sign up for their second tour! The Central tour was very well organized and paced. When you meet they hand you a map with a list of the places you're going and what you're going to eat at each place. The map also shows several other recommended restaurants (including recommended dishes at those places) not on the tour, as well as a few useful phrases. Our first stop was a noodle shop. We got a lot of information about the food and the restaurant, but there was also a greater discussion of local history and culture above and beyond that, which pleasantly surprised us. The next stop was at a roast meat specialist for char siu and rice. We learned about the eight types of roast meats and how to tell the difference between goose and duck. We also got a tour of the kitchen/roasting/drying room. Next we walked by the street stalls on Stanley and learned how there are only about 30 stalls left since they stopped issuing permits in 1980s. We also walked through the local wet market and learned how the market area is being demolished and redeveloped, with all proprietors being moved into a new city building as they prepare to knock down the surrounding buildings. We walked through old and gentrified neighborhoods and truly got a sense of how the city is changing--something we didn't appreciate as much while roaming the streets on our own. Next up, a preserved fruit shop, followed by dim sum at Dim Sum Squared. We finished with warm egg tarts, fresh out of the oven. It was truly an excellent tour, which was not just about the food, but offered a much richer experience of the city as a whole, by meeting local mom and pop proprietors, learning more about local dishes, seeing some of the kitchens and cooks in action, and observing gentrification first hand. We are not tour people, and typically like to do our own research and exploring (especially when it comes to food), but this tour convinced us of the value of a tour, and we're now thinking about taking foodie tours in other cities. It really added so much to our trip. At $90/each (including food at six stops), it was absolutely worth it, and if we're ever in Hong Kong again, we'd take this tour again in a heartbeat.

Really enjoyed this experien - great people!. My husband and I came to Hong Kong in February 2015 and being in China for the first time we had no experience with local food. Booking this tour for the second day of our stay was the best decision ever. The tour was great! Our guides were super friendly and informed us about food, life, history…. Literally everything we wanted to know about Hong Kong.While walking through the streets they showed us street markets, explained the history of the places. They really know their neighbourhood and chatted with lots of people on the way.We ate egg tart, noodles, sweets, dumplings and drank fresh cane sugar juice…Really loved these guys and would definitely book another tour with them. It is not a cheap tour but what you get for it is a great experience and definitely worth the money.

Shui Sham Po. We had a great tour with Fiona Lee on Saturday, Jan. 31. What a great way to tour one of the less western parts of Hong Kong. Ms. Lee knows the area, the history and attributes of the neighborhood well. She did a great job of making everyone comfortable, giving us the background on food and culture. Her English is excellent. The tour was an easy walk, with opportunities to see several markets, and better understand the local foods. We met several wonderful people and thoroughly enjoyed our tour.There were couples, a parent with a child and a solo on our tour. I think we all enjoyed

An excellent introduction to Hong Kong!. We have nothing but compliments for the two guides we had on our first day in Hong Kong. We took the Central tour and found it intriguing and delicious. Our favorite stops were the Noodle House and the BBQ restaurant. Because they were our favorites, we returned to similar restaurants in Kowloon later that week. Our least favorite were the snacks and the sugarcane juice. The guides took us along the back streets, such as "coffin" street and told us many fascinating facts along the way. We highly recommend this experience. The directions to the meeting place were excellent and dispelled any fears of getting lost on our first day in this huge city.

A wonderful blend of walking tour + history + food + efficiency.. I had the pleasure of having Silvana as my tour guide, which was consisting of all foreigners. She did an amazing job! Her explanations, relationships with both vendors and tour group members, guidance, and expertise really showed. We kept very good time and pace on this walking tour.Thanks again Silvana all the best.

Definitely Recommend!. This was a highlight of our trip and much thanks to our wonderful and personable guide, Lillian! The history on the different areas of Hong Hong was very interesting and not something you will find in guide books. The family run restaurants were all welcoming with delicious food. Our favorite were the shrimp wontons, dim sum, and egg tarts. We returned to two the next day with others in our group. This is a great afternoon activity while visiting HK! I would recommend not eating before though because I would have been completely full if I'd finished the first meal!

Food + History + Culture = Totally Worthwhile. This company offers 2 tours, which I took on consecutive days. Both tours have 6 official food- tasting stops, but both also have numerous other stops for local history, culture, and neighbourhood flavour. Both last about 3 1/2 hours. At the start, both give you a printed guide/map not only of the official stops, but of other restaurants/shops of interest in the area. Also you are given bottled water and a packet of tissues (as you may know, Hong Kong eateries are stingy with their napkins). Both feature food-tasting stops at places you probably wouldn't have noticed or tried yourself (the signage and/or menus are mostly only in Chinese). Local, mostly family-owned and operated places, often by multiple generations. Or the business itself may have a long history, or the building may be historic. Many places make their own offerings on-site and via old-fashioned, labourious methods. Food is the main thing, but you learn so much more--totally worthwhile.CENTRAL & SHEUNG WAN FOODIE TOUROffered 4 times per week, 12 people max, 2:15 pm start (to avoid the lunch crowds). Our guides were Sylvana (she's on their website) and Ed, both excellent, both natives. Central is the business and financial centre of Hong Kong island, lots of recognizable high-rise office buildings. Sheung Wan is the rapidly gentrifying area west of Central--"hot" new restaurants, businesses and housing are quickly suffocating the old-style eateries, businesses, wet markets and traditional housing. More than once on this tour, we were told "take pictures now, this may be gone next time you're in Hong Kong", or "every week we see someplace new opening on this tour". Our tour had some Americans, an Aussie, and a South African/Canadian.For me, the food-tasting stops offered many tastings familiar to me, but they were among the best I have tasted. The 6 stops were:1) Wonton noodle shop. Located in a basement, outside sign in Chinese only, menu has English. Family-run and passed down for 3 generations, began as a dai pai dong (a classic open-air food stall still seen all over the city, kind of like an immovable food truck with covered seating). They make their own wontons, fishballs, broth, etc. We had noodles and wonton in broth .The shrimp wontons were HUGE, golf ball-sized, with almost whole fresh shrimp. 2) Roast meat restaurant. Narrow space, popular for take-away. Chinese/English signage, Chinese menu only. Roast meats of all kinds, hanging in the window. We had barbecue pork rice--delish. We were taken into the kitchen to see the large vertical roasting ovens. I would return here another day for take-away.3) Sugar cane juice. An old business in an old colonial-style building, Chinese-only sign. Right in front a man was placing stalks of sugar cane through a machine over and over, slowly breaking it down. The juice was different, but tasty. The place also sells turtle shell jelly.4) Preserved fruit shop. Here we were served a lovely kumquat/lemon tea and given a box of preserved fruits of various types, some of which I remembered from my youth.5) Dim sum. Family-run. Sign and menu in both Chinese and English. Here we were served dim sum classics, among the freshest and best I've had.--shrimp dumplings, pork/shrimp dumplings, deep fried spring rolls, and crispy BBQ pork buns (baos). For me, the baos were a revelation! We're all familiar with the classic steamed white baos, and I'v had many a delish baked bao in the States, but the dough on these baos was totally new for me--chewy with a slight crunch and sweetness not unlike Hong Kong's famous pineapple bun (served on the other tour)--I think it's both baked and fried. And since I would have baos similar to these twice more at other places (Tim Ho Wan, Lung King Heen), I consider this a veritable paradigm shift in the way baked baos are made in Hong Kong!. I must now research to see if such baos exist in Los Angeles! I would return here on my own another day. Go after the lunch crowd. You are given a menu and pencil to place your order; there are photos or each item on the tables. The baos here were the cheapest of the 3 places I tried.6) Bakery/pastry shop. Chinese/English signage. For take-away, no dining area--we were eating on the narrow sidewalk and street. We were served a classic egg tart, but this too was new and revelatory for me because the tart had a shortcrust pastry, as in shortbread-like, as in butter, butter, butter! Egg tarts I've had before, in the US and here, must have had shortening or lard crusts, including some place we went to on my first visit here, guided by an English publication's recommendation, where we ate the tarts on the street as buses full of locals laughed at us. This was the best and biggest egg tart I've had.Non-tasting stops included some dai pai dongs under the Mid-Level escalators (which the government is threatening to close for sanitation reasons), Graham St. wet market, also slated for redevelopment (massive construction already encroaches one side), a dried seafood shop, a Dr. Sun Yat-Sen shout-out, Man Mo Temple, Cat St. (which has 2 other names), a snake shop (for soup).I had walked many of these streets before (this was my 5th Hong Kong visit), but I learned so much and discovered new places to return to in the future on this tour. Hopefully, they'll still be there next time. As an aside, I would find out later that Sylvana is an Eilte-level Yelper. She kind of dissed a new restaurant in Central the International New York Times raved about (and was also mentioned in Travel & Leisure magazine) that I was planning to try. I ended up not going, not because of her diss, but because I was too mellow after a great spa treatment to leave my hotel. Maybe next time, if it's still there.SHAM SHUI PO FOODIE TOUROffered 3 times a week, 8 people max, 9:15 am start. Our guide was the excellent Fiona. Sham Shui Po is on the Kowloon side of Hong Kong, somewhat north of the Tsim Sha Tsui harbourfront. It seems like kind of a working-class neighbourhood, with older walk-up residential buildings (complete with laundry hanging out of many a window), busy street markets filled more with locals than tourists, no modern skyscrapers like in Central. Much more local colour and flavour. The tour began in the MTR station, which Fiona told us all have restrooms--you have to ask an employee to guide you. Everyone but me on our tour was Aussie. Before the tour started, I did a restroom stop at a nearby McDonald's, where they served some quasi-Asian dishes and red bean pies, as well as apple pies.These food stops offered a few tastings that were new to me. The 6 stops were:1) Hong Kong-stlye cafe. No English anywhere. Here we had milk tea and pineapple buns. The milk tea was strong but good. The pineapple buns were outstanding. Some of us commented on how large they were, but there was nary a crumb left when we were through. It was like eating a soft but crunchy and sweet cloud. We got a peek at the buns being made, the ovens, and a man making the milk tea by straining it many times through what looked like a ladies' stocking.2) Chinese-style breakfast. Tiny place, no English anywhere, long queue for take-away. No tables were free, so Fiona told us to look for a table that looked like they were about finished, and then basically hover and breathe down their necks until they were done. We ended up squeezing into a table where a single local man took his merry time finishing his congee. We were served rice rolls--sheets of rice "pasta" rolled up jelly-roll style and then cut into bit-sized pieces. You sauce them with peanut and hoisin sauces and a sprinkling of sesame seeds. They are eaten with wooden skewers (like a long toothpick) because they're too slippery for chopsticks. Delish, and new to me. Great local experience.3) Soy product shop. No English. They only serve 3 soy products, which are made on-site--we saw the machinery/methods. Most of us tried the tofu dessert, ladled out of a big pot in thin layers, served hot with ginger syrup and sugar. Pretty good; I've had it before in the US, but not with ginger. Two people opted for the soybean milk, served warm or chilled.4) Braised meat shop. No English. Apparently a Chiu Chow-Hong Kong fusion. We had braised goose and pork knuckle served with a dipping sauce and rice. Delish. I think this is the first time I've had goose--it tastes very similar to duck, but is more expensive. 5) Traditional Chinese bakery. No English. Here we were given a packet of cookies--walnut, almond and sesame. Some gobbled theirs then and there, I saved mine for later--also delish.6) Noodle shop.
